project.name: EU GDPR
project.desc: This library provides a set of development requirements that help comply with EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) (EU) 2016/679.

componentDefinition.name: EU GDPR Environment
componentDefinition.desc: Choose this component if the application handles EU citizen personal data

component.name: Component with UI
component.desc: A component that exposes an interface to a user, this could be a GUI or an API

weakness.name: No process to edit and update personal data
weakness.desc: No process through which the data subject can directly modify their personal information which is no longer correct.

weakness.name: No public privacy notice
weakness.desc:
• No or incomplete privacy notice
  • Privacy notice not findable for data subjects within the application
  • Privacy notice not given within 72 hours after data was gathered directly or indirectly from data subject
Data subject = person of whom personal data is processed

weakness.name: No consent mechanism (conform GDPR & E-privacy Regulation)
weakness.desc: No consent mechanisms (or a consent mechanism that does not comply with the GDPR and E-privacy legislation consent requirements) so the organization is unable prove to data protection authorities that the processing is legitimate/legal.

weakness.name: No export functionality
weakness.desc: No exportability functionality (for users or admins) which would allow the user to (directly or indirectly via an admin) export his personal data in a clear, readable format and transport it to another data controller.

weakness.name: Lack of functionality to view personal data provided
weakness.desc: No user functionality or information within application which can be used by data subjects to access his personal data or request his personal data.

control.name: Implement export functionality
control.desc:
All data gathered from a user should be exportable. This does not include derived fields that were created by the organization, such as customer segmentation fields.

Provide or develop the means that will contribute to answer data portability requests, such as download tools or Application Programming Interfaces (API).

They should guarantee that personal data are transmitted in a structured, commonly used and machine-readable format, and they should be encouraged to ensure the interoperability of the data format provided in the exercise of a data portability request.
see also - http://ec.europa.eu/newsroom/document.cfm?doc_id=44099 (Guidelines on the right to "data portability" by WP29)"

test.steps:
1. Verify users have the functionality to request personal data transfer and/or download their own data.
  2. Verify data is in a form acceptable to the Data Protection Practitioner.

control.name: Implement the process to edit personal data
control.desc:
Individuals are entitled to have personal data rectified if it is inaccurate or incomplete.
Provide a form or API for users to update or correct their data. If the personal data is shared with other systems you should also update the data there. Ensure that all data submitted by the user can be modified. No personal data should be read-only.

test.steps:
1. Verify users have the ability to edit inaccurate personal information either directly or via a form within the application user interface.
  2. Ensure these personal data changes are replicated throughout the operational environment.

control.name: Integrate a privacy notice within the application

test.steps:
1. Verify users have easy access to privacy notices within the application interface.
  2. Verify privacy notices are presented to the user before they submit their personal data.
  3. Verify privacy notices are in accordance with the requirements of the Data Protection practitioner.

control.name: Provide a communication channel for the data subject for privacy questions
control.desc:
Provide a communication channel for the data subject for privacy questions (within the application or through other means (example. privacy@organization.com) and make it possible to export data so that you could provide an overview of all data that was delivered/imported by the data subject within the application.

(Implementation Tip: Facebook has a functionality which allows users to manually request the right to information. This request automatically generates a downloadable report which includes all information that was gathered from the data subject).

test.steps:
1. Verify users have the functionality available within the application interface for easy contact routes for privacy questions.
  2. Verify operational mechanisms are in place to gather all user personal data processed by the application and export that data to the user.

control.name: Create a consent mechanism
control.desc:
Implement a consent mechanism which allows data subjects (persons of whom personal data is processed) to give their consent for certain processing activities. This is mainly used for cookies and secondary purposes such as direct marketing, newsletters, ...

The consent mechanism often consists of a check box. These check boxes are required for every single secondary purpose (not allowed to implement one consent box for all purposes). The consent boxes should:
  • be inactive by default (the data subject should active the box)
  • revocable (the data subject must be able to revoke the consent in a way that is as easy as it was to give consent, this can be done by implementing a platform on which the data subject can actively manage his/her consents)
  • Traceable (a consent database is required to track when consent was given and revoked. This must include timestamps)

You must involve the DPO and/or legal department to decide on the legitimation that can be used.

test.steps:
1. Verify appropriate user personal data consent mechanisms are in place and are not pre-granted.
  2. Verify users can modify their data consent choices in a manner as easy as giving consent.
  3. Verify the above above user activities have been appropriately logged.

threat.name: Subjects cannot exercise their rights over their personal data
threat.desc:
Data subject cannot exercise their rights which makes it possible for data subjects to file a complaint at local Data Protection Authority which might lead to administrative fines.

Data subject = person of whom personal data is processed

threat.name: Lack of Data Subject Control
threat.desc: Processing personal data can only happen if the data subject has been properly informed. Processing personal data without proper notice makes it possible for data subjects to file a complaint at local Data Protection Authority which might lead to administrative fines.

threat.name: Illegal processing of personal data
threat.desc: Processing personal data without legal grounds which makes it possible for data subjects to file a complaint at local Data Protection Authority which might lead to administrative fines.

component.name: International Transfer
component.desc: Transfer of data to third countries

weakness.name: No legal ground used for international data transfer to third countries
weakness.desc:
• No binding corporate rules or standard model clauses with non-EU third party
  • Inadequate due diligence of third parties

control.name: Manage international data transfers
control.desc: You must involve the DPO/Legal in order to ensure that the international transfer of data is legal. The DPO can make use of adequacy decisions, Binding Corporate Rules (BCRs), standard EU model clauses or derivatives (Privacy shield) whenever they apply.

test.steps: Verify international transfer of user personal data to non-EU countries is compliant with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.

threat.name: Illegal processing of personal data

weakness.desc:
Storing too much personal data of data subjects which might lead to negative consequences for the data subject (e.g. a large amount of data might lead to invasive profiling, identity

weakness.desc:
Storing personal data too long might lead to negative consequences for the data subject (e.g. a large amount of data might lead to invasive profiling, identity theft, ...)

Data subject = person of whom data is processed.

weakness.name: Insufficient anonymisation or pseudonymisation
weakness.desc:
Personal data which is not - or incorrectly - anonymized or pseudonymized is more vulnerable to malicious personal data processing because the data subjects are more easily identifiable.

Data subject = person of whom data is processed.

weakness.desc:
Storing personal data too long might lead to negative consequences for the data subject (e.g. a large amount of data might lead to invasive profiling, identity theft, ...)

Data subject = person of whom data is processed.

weakness.name: Production data used in a test environment
weakness.desc: Production data is stored in a less protected test environment where personal data is easier breached and other security controls are in place.

weakness.name: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data
weakness.desc:
• Weak encryption algorithms
  • Loss of encryption keys
  • Compromised encryption keys
  • Revoked keys are still active (bad key lifecycle management)

weakness.name: Unauthenticated data access
weakness.desc: Authentication can be bypassed.

control.name: Permanently delete unnecessary data
control.desc: Ensure that personal data is automatically deleted, within operational and back-up environments, whenever the defined retention periods have expired. This requires automatic identification of latest activities within the database (timestamping logging) and a data deletion functionality.

test.steps:
1. Verify personal data timestamp logging is in place indicating the time period in which the data was obtained from the user.
  2. Verify completion of automatic personal data deletion after mandated retention time-period has elapsed.

control.name: Require authentication before presenting restricted data
control.desc:
The application should ensure users have undergone an Identification and Verification (ID&V) process before allowing access to secret, sensitive or otherwise restricted data. For less sensitive but still restricted data, simple verification of the location of the user may suffice (e.g. IP restrictions).
  • For non-sensitive but non-public data, access could be restricted by IP address, for example limiting access to internal networks, workstations, or gateways
  • For more sensitive data, TLS client-side certificates may be appropriate
  • Where secret or other sensitive data is handled, a full authentication process to identify and validate users with single or multi-factor authentication may be required

test.steps:
1. Identify which parts of the service present sensitive data. 
  2. Try to obtain access to this information without any type of authentication, for example, attempt to navigate directly to URLs that present sensitive data.

control.name: Anonymisation/pseudonimisation the data
control.desc:
Implement anonymization/pseudonymization or give a risk based explanation (from the standpoint of the data subject) why anonymization and pseudonymization are not used. Anonymization makes it impossible to reidentify the data subject while pseudonymization uses randomization techniques to make personal data less identifiable.

The following techniques provide a degree of anonymization and pseudonymization and might be used:
  • noise addition 
  • substitution 
  • aggregation or K-anonymity 
  • L-diversity 
  • differential privacy 
  • hashing or tokenization
  • dummy data

test.steps:
1. Verify anonymized data is stripped of ALL personally identifiable information. It should be impossible to reidentify specific users.
  2. Verify additional data would be required to reidentify a specific user when leveraging data pseudonymization.

control.name: Apply authorization checks to segregate and control access to user data
control.desc:
Applications protecting sensitive or otherwise restricted resources must ensure only appropriate and authorized users may access the application data. It is important that an application prevents unauthorized users gaining inappropriate access to each other's data; although user A and user B may both be trusted to access data within the application, they may be authorized to only access different subsets of the protected resources.  E.g. user A should not be able to access user B's personal data by manipulating a request (typical examples are manipulation of an ID value or other object reference sent in the URL or body of an HTTP request).

It is not sufficient to rely on obscurity, for example obfuscated or secret URLs or filenames. The application must validate each request for protected data against the proven identity of the user. Before providing access to restricted resources the application must:
  • Ensure the user has undergone appropriate authentication (identification and verification, or ID&V). E.g. they must have provided their identity and confirmed this with a password, token, or other verification. Typically this will be through checking the validity of the session token issued after login.
  • Confirm the user is entitled to access the data or resource they are requesting. E.g. their confirmed identify checked against a server-side access control matrix to determine whether they may access the requested resource.
  • Access controls should be granular, and allow for access to individual resources to be issued to individual users or roles.
URL and asset based access control is provided by most web-frameworks, and it is preferable to use an established and proven framework.

test.steps:
1. Using two different browsers configured with an intercepting proxy.
  2. Login as user A in browser A.
  3. Login as user B in browser B.
  4. For every operation that displays sensitive data belonging to user A:
    1. Perform the operation as user A and view their sensitive data
    2. Obtain the session ID of user B
    3. Configure the proxy to intercept
    4. Perform the operation as user A again, but this time intercept all the requests and replace user A's session ID with that of user B
    5. Ensure that user A's sensitive data is not visible

control.name: Use anonymised data in test environment
control.desc:
Implement anonymization/pseudonymization or give a risk based explanation (from the standpoint of the data subject) why anonymization and pseudonymization are not used. Anonymization makes it impossible to reidentify the data subject while pseudonymization uses randomization techniques to make personal data less identifiable.

The following techniques provide a degree of anonymization and pseudonymization and might be used:
  • noise addition 
  • substitution 
  • aggregation or K-anonymity 
  • L-diversity 
  • differential privacy 
  • hashing or tokenization
  • dummy data

If anonymization/pseudonymization is not possible, other security controls should be implemented, such as:
  • strong logical access control to test environment
  • deletion of test environment data after tests have been conducted

test.steps:
1. Verify anonymization / pseudonymization of all user personal data is leveraged for data residing within the test environment (truly anonymized data is stripped of ALL personally identifiable information and additional data would be required to reidentify a specific user when leveraging data pseudonymization).
  2. If anonymization / pseudonymization is not leveraged for user personal data residing within the test environment, verify documentation exists justifying why this is and ensure security is as robust as the production environment.

control.name: Define the retention periods of the data
control.desc:
Define retention periods within the design phase for all data fields taking into account the defined purpose. These retention periods can be variable (e.g. 5 years after latest interaction with data subject). Retention periods for back-ups should also be included.

You must include your DPO/Legal department to define the retention periods as other laws may impact the retention requirements.

test.steps:
1. Verify documentation exists which details user personal data retention policy requirements for all user personal data submitted within the application user interface.
  2. Ensure the above is in accordance with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.
  3. Check if user personal data exists within the operational environment that exceeds the age of the retention policy.

control.name: Encrypt personal data
control.desc:
Implement encryption at rest (see guidance below) or give risk-based explanation why encryption was not implemented.

Use well known encryption libraries, taking into account the data use, and do not invent your own.
  • personal data must be encrypted
  • data that is not used by the application (e.g. passwords, ...) should be hashed so they cannot be recovered easily

test.steps:
1. Verify user personal data processed by the application is encrypted at rest (eg databases).
  2. If encryption is not being leveraged verify documentation exists outlining the reasoning for that decision.

control.name: Document all data processed
control.desc: All data fields used by the application need to be documented as to why they are required taking into account the defined purpose. This should be done within the design phase as only data fields that support the defined finality may be included within the application. Open text fields should also be avoided unless there is a very good reason as to why they are needed.

test.steps:
1. Verify documentation exists detailing the purpose for all personal data requested within the application user interface.
  2. Verify users are unable to submit extraneous unnecessary personal data within the application user interface.

threat.name: Data leakage or disclosure to unauthorized parties
threat.desc: Unauthorized party might access/breach the personal data of the data subject.

component.name: Application
component.desc: This threats and countermeasures in this pattern apply to the entire application, if any of the components of the application handle EU personal data. This pattern should be imported once per application.

weakness.name: Lack of breach report within 72 hours
weakness.desc:
No notification of data breaches towards the Data Protection Authority and Data Subjects.

Data Subject = Person of whom personal data is processed

weakness.name: Not a clear purpose
weakness.desc: No clear or unethical purpose for the processing of personal data. Without a clear purpose the application can also be unnecessary from a business perspective.

weakness.name: No public interest
weakness.desc: Application is not created for a specific governmental agency (e.g. law enforcement, courts, intelligence agencies, ...) which may process personal data because it is in the public interest of society.

weakness.name: No contract
weakness.desc: No contract which can be used to prove to data protection authorities that the processing is legitimate/legal.

weakness.name: No legitimate interest
weakness.desc:
No (documented) reasoning which proves that the benefits of the processing organization outweigh the potential negative consequences for the data subject.

Data subject = person of whom data is processed.

weakness.name: No vital interest
weakness.desc:
No situation in which personal data processing might safe the life of the data subjects and therefore makes personal data processing legal.

Data subject = person of whom data is processed.

weakness.name: No legal base
weakness.desc: No other law (lex specialis) which overrides the GDPR (lex generalis) which makes the personal data processing required/legal.

weakness.name: No incident management process/IRT
weakness.desc: No or ineffective incident response team and/or process causing an ineffective containment and treatment of data breaches.

weakness.name: No (proactive) auditing
weakness.desc: Harder to conduct forensic analysis after an attack succeeds in order to pinpoint the source of the attack.

weakness.name: No detection mechanism/process
weakness.desc: The non-existence or inefficiency of data breach processes and tools.

control.name: Document the vital interests for processing
control.desc:
You must involve the DPO and/or legal department to decide on the legitimation that can be used.

Document if/why the vital interests for processing can be used.

test.steps:
1. Verify documentation exists detailing "vital interest" justification for processing personal data.
  2. Verify "vital interest" justification is in compliance with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.

control.name: Document the public interests for processing
control.desc:
You must involve the DPO and/or legal department to decide on the legitimation that can be used.

Document if/why the public interests for processing can be used.

test.steps:
1. Verify documentation exists detailing "public interest" justification for processing user personal data.
  2. Verify "public interest" justifications are in compliance with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.

control.name: Create reporting templates & process
control.desc: Ensure that your organization has a process and templates for reporting data breaches towards the data protection authority and data subjects.

test.steps: Verify processes and templates exist for reporting data breaches of user personal data to affected users and the data protection authority within 72 hours of becoming aware of the incident.

control.name: Implement a monitoring tool
control.desc:
Make sure that all access to personal data is logged.

Implement a monitoring tool (e.g. SIEM) in order to automatically notify potential data breaches and/or implement process so that employees and data subjects (persons of whom personal data is processed) can manually report potential breaches.

test.steps:
1. Test accessing user personal data as legitimate users, employees, administrators and malicious actors.
  2. Verify all the above activities are successfully logged.
  3. Verify "suspicious" activity generated by mimicking an malicious actor is detected and relevant security personnel alerted by security monitoring tools.
  4. Verify employees and users have a mechanism whereby they can manually report known, potential, or suspected data breaches.

control.name: Present Personal information contract

test.steps:
1. Verify users are presented with the Personal Information Contract policy when registering with the application.
  2. Verify the Personal Information Contract policy notice is in compliance with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.

control.name: Implement a monitoring system to alert the SOC operators
control.desc: Implement a monitoring system to alert the SOC operators of suspicious behaviors and potential data breaches. The purpose of proactive monitoring is to prevent data breaches or stop an active data breach before personal data is exfiltrated and hereby ensure adequate information security of personal data.

test.steps:
1. Test accessing user personal data mimicking the "suspicious" behavior of an malicious actor and verify activities are detected and relevant security personnel alerted by monitoring tools.
  2. Test unauthorized user personal data exfiltration and verify this is detected and relevant security personnel alerted by monitoring tools.

control.name: Document legal grounds for processing
control.desc:
You must involve the DPO and/or legal department to decide on the legal legitimation that can be used.

You must document the legal base that can be used.

test.steps:
1. Verify documentation exists detailing the legal justification for processing all user personal data.
  2. Ensure this document complies with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.

control.name: Create mechanisms for the treatment of potential data breaches
control.desc: Create an Incident Response Management Process for the treatment of potential data breaches. This process should involve the DPO and provide sufficient factual data to the DPO.

test.steps: Verify Incident Management Process documentation exists for dealing with potential data breaches and is compliant with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.

control.name: Define the purpose of the data processing
control.desc:
The purpose of the application must be formally documented. This purpose serves as the input for different controls as the processing purpose must be legitimated and all used data fields can only be used if it can be shown that they are required for the documented purpose.

The purpose should also be used in order to document the functional requirements of the application. Functional requirements should be limited to the documented purpose.

test.steps: Verify documentation exists detailing the purpose for all user personal data requested within the application user interface.

control.name: Evaluate if legitimate interests can be applied + document reasoning
control.desc:
You must involve the DPO and/or legal department to decide on the legitimation that can be used.

Evaluate if legitimate interests can be applied. This is an assessment of why the rights of the organization outweigh the risks of a data subject.

test.steps:
1. Verify with the Data Protection Practitioner, user personal data being processed by the application falls within "acceptable" boundaries regarding the benefits to the organization vs the potential negative consequences for the user.
  2. Verify this is documented.

threat.desc: Processing personal data without legal grounds which makes it possible for data subjects to file a complaint at local Data Protection Authority which might lead to administrative fines.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring and incident response
threat.desc: Attackers can gain undetected access to sensitive data without detection.

threat.name: Failure to report a breach can result in financial penalties
threat.desc: Data subjects are unaware of a breach and cannot take measures in order to minimize the impact of the attack and prevent reoccurence. Also the rights of the data subjects are not ensured by a follow-up investigation of the local data protection authority.

weakness.desc: Authorization can be bypassed

weakness.name: Unrecovered sensitive data
weakness.desc: The sensitive data cannot be recovered after the data has been accidentally or intentionally deleted due to non-existent data backup.

weakness.name: Profiling algorithms that lead to erroneous profiles
weakness.desc: Bad algorithms which lead to erroneous profiles.

weakness.name: Insufficient input validation
weakness.desc: No logical checks to see if personal data which is uploaded into the application is correct (e.g. format requirements, input possibility controls, ...)

weakness.name: Unauthenticated data access
weakness.desc: Authentication can be bypassed.

weakness.name: Insufficient Logging
No data integrity checks
weakness.desc: Inadequate integrity protection (e.g. encryption, strong logical access rights, ...) which leaves personal data vulnerable towards man in the middle attacks.

weakness.name: Not data deletion functionality
weakness.desc:
Personal data is not automatically deleted when retention periods have expired, which means data must be manually deleted by an administrator who can easily forget this task.

Personal data that was deleted becomes operational again after a restore because the data was not deleted from the back-ups nor was there a process in place to reidentify and delete personal data that was previously deleted.

control.name: Logging the data access and the modification of personal data
control.desc: Make sure that every access and modification of personal data is logged (The log should be precise enough to know who changed what and when). This includes data access from the application as well as data access from privileged accounts, such as database admins. In practice, this means logging both on application, middleware and operating system (OS) level.

test.steps:
1. Test accessing and modifying user personal data as legitimate users, employees, administrators and malicious actors.
  2. Verify appropriate logging of all the above activities are successful and sufficiently detailed.

  2. Try to obtain access to this information without any type of authentication, for example, attempt to navigate directly to URLs that present sensitive data.

control.name: Implement input validation controls
control.desc:
Implement input validation controls to ensure personal data is captured correctly. This may include:
  1. Input validation based on business logic rules (All data needs to be validated before processing. Ensure the type of data is checked as well its range when applicable (e.g : age between 0 and 150)
  2. Restrict input to trusted sources (Eg. E-ID) and formats
  3. Let the data subject (=person of whom personal data is processed) manually input his/her data and/or review his data before submitting
  4. Review & Resolution of errors (Supplemental Guidance: Resolution of input validation errors includes, for example, correcting systemic causes of errors and resubmitting transactions with corrected input)

test.steps:
1. Verify user personal data is properly formed with strong validation patterns both syntactically (eg dates) and semantically (eg age is within expected range).
  2. Test by attempting to submit malformed and logically invalid personal data into the user interface.

control.name: Implement data sanity and data integrity checks
control.desc: Implement data sanity and data integrity checks. Data sanity checks are run on a regular basis to validate the sanity of the data (e.g. through statistical analysis). Data integrity checks are performed when data is entered or changed to ensure the data complies to business validation rules as well as common sense rules (e.g. age should not be over 130 years)

test.steps: Test if users are able to submit malformed, invalid, untrusted, unauthorized data leveraging an intercepting proxy. Especially consider the issue of bypassing non-editable controls such as hidden-fields

control.name: Implement a Backup and Recovery process
control.desc:
Ensure backup policy is active and tested.The policy should describe the required recovery time objective (RTO) and recovery point objective (RPO) so that the availability of personal data can be restored in a timely manner (based upon the requirements specified by the DPO/CISO).

Ensure an SLA has been defined for data availability. How 'timely manner' will be interpreted depends on your SLA.

test.steps:
1. Verify backup policy documentation exists that are up-to-date and in compliance with the requirements of the Data Protection Practitioner.
  2. Regularly test data backup procedures and data restoration.

control.name: Implement forget user functionality
control.desc:
Make sure that your deletion functionality also facilitates the manual deletion of one data subject (person of whom personal data is processed) at any given point in time. All data of the data subject should be deleted from the operational databases as well as back-ups.

Implementation Advice: You should develop a script to ensure the re-deletion of data subjects (persons of whom personal data is processed) who exercised their right to be forgotten and run it after each database restore. The data subjects should be deleted from the script whenever the retention period of the data has expired.

test.steps:
1. Verify the capability to delete a user's personal data from within operational storage.
  2. Verify this user data will not be reactivated during restoration of data backup.

control.name: Automated decisions and profiling
control.desc: You must involve the DPO to make sure that automated decisions are ethical and correct and to make sure that data subjects can object to the profiling activities (foresee a secondary process that can manually bypass the processing).

test.steps:
1. Verify with the Data Protection Practitioner the reasoning for automatically gathering personal data from users for profiling purposes is compliant and justified with their requirements.
  2. Verify user mechanisms are in place to object to these profiling activities.

threat.name: Lack of detectability and evidence
threat.desc: Attackers can gain undetected access to sensitive data and they are not monitored.

threat.name: Loss of personal data
threat.desc: Personal data can be lost by (accidental or malicious) deletion and system failures.

threat.desc:
Data subject cannot exercise their rights which makes it possible for data subjects to file a complaint at local Data Protection Authority which might lead to administrative fines.

threat.desc: Processing personal data without legal grounds which makes it possible for data subjects to file a complaint at local Data Protection Authority which might lead to administrative fines.

threat.name: Incorrect or corrupt data which is used for processing
